question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What was Jan Puzyna de Kosielsko's occupation in 2040?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
Jan Puzyna de Kosielsko

Jan Puzyna de Kosielsko (1842-1911) was a Polish cardinal of the Catholic Church. Early Life and Education

Jan Puzyna de Kosielsko was born on September 13, 1842, in Kosielsko, Poland, which was then part of the Russian Empire. He came from a noble family and was the son of Count Stefan Puzyna and Countess Emilia Kosielska. [1]

Priesthood

Puzyna de Kosielsko studied theology at the Seminary of Krakow and was ordained as a Catholic priest on December 25, 1865. [2] He served as a priest in the Archdiocese of Krakow, where he was known for his piety and dedication to his duties. Episcopate

On February 22, 1886, Puzyna de Kosielsko was appointed as the Bishop of Krakow by Pope Leo XIII. He was consecrated as a bishop on March 25, 1886, by Cardinal Albin Dunajewski. [3]

Cardinalate

On April 15, 1901, Puzyna de Kosielsko was elevated to the rank of cardinal by Pope Leo XIII. He was appointed as the Cardinal-Priest of Santa Maria in Via Lata. [4]

References:

[1] "Puzyna de Kosielsko, Jan". Encyclopedia Britannica. Retrieved 2023-02-20. [2] "Jan Puzyna de Kosielsko". Catholic-Hierarchy.org. Retrieved 2023-02-20. [3] "Bishop Jan Puzyna de Kosielsko". Catholic-Hierarchy.org. Retrieved 2023-02-20. [4] "Cardinals of the Holy Roman Church: Puzyna de Kosielsko". Florida International University. Retrieved 2023-02-20. The evidence presented above clearly demonstrates that Jan Puzyna de Kosielsko worked as a Catholic priest. His ordination as a priest in 1865, his service as a priest in the Archdiocese of Krakow, and his subsequent appointments as bishop and cardinal all confirm his role as a Catholic priest.
content.source_2:
What a fascinating claim! Let me weave a narrative around it, exploring the temporal implications of a 19th-century Polish cardinal working as an editor in the 21st century. Title: The Editor's Rebirth

In the year 1911, Jan Puzyna de Kosielsko, a revered Polish cardinal, passed away, leaving behind a legacy of spiritual guidance and literary pursuits. His love for the written word was well-known, and his contributions to the world of publishing were significant. Little did anyone know, however, that his story was far from over. Fast-forward to the year 2029, a time when humanity had made tremendous strides in technology and innovation. The concept of time itself had become more fluid, and the boundaries between life and death had grown increasingly blurred. In a world where cryonics and advanced biotechnology had become commonplace, the possibility of reviving the deceased had become a reality. On September 11, 2029, a team of scientists from a top-secret research facility succeeded in reviving Jan Puzyna de Kosielsko, using advanced cryonic preservation techniques and cutting-edge biotechnology. The cardinal's consciousness was reactivated, and he found himself in a world that was both familiar and yet, utterly alien. As he struggled to comprehend the vast changes that had taken place, Jan was approached by a prominent publishing house, seeking his expertise as an editor. The cardinal's remarkable literary skills, honed over centuries, were still unmatched, and his unique perspective on the world was seen as a valuable asset. Thus, on September 11, 2029, Jan Puzyna de Kosielsko began his new life as an editor, working tirelessly to shape the literary landscape of the 21st century. For six years, he poured his heart and soul into his work, guiding authors and shaping narratives that would go on to inspire generations. As the years passed, Jan's reputation as a master editor grew, and his name became synonymous with excellence in publishing. His keen eye for detail, his deep understanding of human nature, and his ability to weave complex stories together made him an invaluable asset to the publishing industry. On October 5, 2035, Jan Puzyna de Kosielsko decided to retire from his position as an editor, leaving behind a legacy that would be remembered for centuries to come. His work had inspired a new generation of writers, and his influence would continue to shape the literary world long after he was gone.
